text: Hi, Angie.
Hi, George.
Hey, Ruth. What are you doing here?
Honey, you remember Ruth.
From the bakery? Hell, yeah.
From church. And peace be with you, sister.
Here, have a seat.

So, Ruth, did you come here about the
cleaning job?

Well, I saw on the bulletin board that you
were looking for help one day a week, and I
need something to keep me busy.

Honey, having Ruth here would be much better
than some stranger.

No offense, Ruth, but the person we hire has
to do some pretty tough work around here.
Oh, I raised three boys.
I can handle anything.
And it's a little bit of a bribe.
I brought you some muffins.

Well, no offense to it, but I'm not making
any decisions based on a muffin.

It's a big deal for me to bring someone into
my house.
Oh. Oh.

There's pudding in the middle. I can't
believe it.
You start tomorrow, senora.
You're fired. Again, again?
I think I got it all.
I know, but it just feels good.
Oh, okay.
Okay. All done.
You see, that wasn't so bad, was it?
You said if I sat still, I'd get a surprise.
Yes, I did, and it's in the kitchen.

When you told me you'd never had a birthday
cake when you were a kid, it just broke my

heart. So to make up for that, I baked you a
cake from scratch.
What does from scratch mean?
It means I made it with my own hands.
Just for you.
And there is one special ingredient.
Love.

Uh, cinnamon. Oh, but sure, sure, there's
love in there somewhere.

Now, my boys used to love to ice their own
cakes.

So here you try it and write anything you
want.
Thanks, mom.
Oh. How sweet.
Oh. Oh.
Are you. Are you getting sick again?
Your eyes are all watery.

No, it just looks like there's a lot of
cinnamon in that cake.
You know, a lot of cinnamon.
Ruth? What happened?
It's a mess in here.

Oh, I'm sorry, I meant to get to it, but we
had had such a busy Saturday.

Sometimes I wish I could just cross my arms,
blink my eyes and make things happen.
Thanks, mom.
You made me a cake.
That's not for you.

George, can I speak to you in the living
room?

Can we make it quick? Because Ruth is taking
me to the movies.
And she said I could pick the candy.

I'm gonna pick the one that looks like
worms. And after you eat them, you like-.

It's been two weeks, and I've talked to her,
but the house is still a mess.
We need to let her go.
No.
No way.

She's not doing the job we're paying her to
do.
I know what this is about.

You can't stand it that someone likes me
more than you.
Sick. Saint Angie is finally off her throne.
Saints don't have thrones.
Yeah. That's nice. Correct.

Everyone you run into, that'll make you more
friends.
I just want a clean house.

And if Ruth can't do the work, we'll have to
get someone else.

You know what? When I get back from my
meeting, I'll tell her it's not working out.
No, you
don't even know her. I'll take care of it.

I know I have a lot of work, but I thought
you two might like a piece of cake.
Here's one for you and one for you.
Ha ha ha. Mine's bigger.
Thank you. Ruth.

George, was there something you wanted to
talk to Ruth about?
Ruth.
It's not working out.
What?
It's not working out.
Oh, sweetie, I'll get you a glass of milk.
